thread.title: Search suspended for missing woman Carissa Avison
thread.title_full: Search suspended for missing woman Carissa Avison

title: Search suspended for missing woman Carissa Avison
text:
Search suspended for missing woman Carissa Avison Last updated 10:49, February 3 2017 SUPPLIED 
Carissa Avison is shown exiting a lift at an address on the North Shore about 10am on 26 January. 
Police have suspended their search for missing Auckland woman Carissa Avison. 
Search and Rescue teams, as well as family and friends, scoured the Woodhill Forest and Muriwai area north of Auckland for six days in the search for the 21-year-old after she went missing on January 26. 
"After carefully reviewing all information over the last week and completing a series of detailed searches in areas where we believe Carissa may have been, police have made the decision to suspend the search," Detective Senior Sergeant Iain Chapman said on Friday morning. SUPPLIED 
Missing Auckland woman Carissa Avison 
"Should any further information come to light, this will be carefully reviewed and the search may be resumed. 
READ MORE: * Missing Auckland woman Carissa Avison went to Muriwai before disappearing 
"We know that Woodhill Forest is a very busy recreational area and we continue to ask members of the public who may be in the area over the long weekend to get in touch with us if they see anything that may be relevant to the investigation." 
Avison's last known movements were on Thursday, January 26, when she was driven from Holder Pl to Coast Rd in Muriwai where she arrived at 11am. 
She left her home on Dockside Lane in Auckland Central about 8.30am that morning, apparently heading to work in Auckland's CBD. 
She has not been seen or heard from since. 
Avison was seen at the Hunting and Fishing store on Holder Pl in Rosedale on the North Shore about 10am. Ad Feedback 
Sources said Avison, who held a firearms licence, bought a gun at the store, but police refused to comment. 
Police don't know why she was heading to Muriwai and said the driver did not know Avison and was in no way involved. They would not comment on why the driver took her to Muriwai. 
Anyone with information can contact Detective Senior Sergeant Iain Chapman at Auckland Police on 09 302 6400 or report anonymously by calling Crimestoppers on 0800 555 111. - Stuff
